awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Mass Extinction Ecological Response and Recovery in the Cretaceous/Paleogene Gulf Coastal Plain
awd_abstract_narration:
It is largely unknown how marine animals today will respond to current and future environmental change. This research is using the geologic record of a mass extinction event 66 million years ago as a natural laboratory to understand habitat loss and species survival during rapid environmental changes. The systematically collected paleo-environment and fossil data are the foundation of immersive, online 'Virtual Field Experiences' that engage students with the field collection and lab processing methods of Earth Sciences research. Online experiences and lesson plans aligned with Next Generation Science Standards are broadly available through well-known online portals and disseminated to teachers in the Gulf Coast states.

Periods of extreme, rapid environmental change in Earth history are informative for predicting current and future survivorship in response to changing climate. These events also provide the opportunity to test hypotheses on macroevolutionary pattern and process. This project involves compiling species occurrences and paleoenvironments across the end-Cretaceous mass extinction (~66 Ma) in the U.S. Gulf Coastal Plain. Topics of investigation include (1) the impact of available suitable habitat and habitat continuity on extinction potential; (2) the impact of extreme environmental change on patterns of niche stability within species, and phylogenetic niche conservation within clades; and (3) the influence of extreme environmental change on macroecological shifts in body size and physiological flexibility. This research supports three female early-career PIs, and graduate and undergraduate students at five institutions (two of which serve non-traditional, minority-majority student populations) are trained in field, laboratory, and analytical Earth Science. Two Virtual Field Experiences with high school-level lesson plans will emphasize hypothesis testing and the significance of extinction events.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
When a massive asteroid struck the Earth 66 million years ago, it led to the extinction of the dinosaurs and many other forms of life, including those living in the oceans. Our team of scientists and students from the Paleontological Research Institution and The College of William and Mary have been working to understand how this event, known as the Cretaceous-Paleogene (K-Pg) mass extinction, shaped the history of marine life near where the asteroid struck. A project focused on the fossils of the U.S. Gulf Coastal Plain (GCP) is providing new insights into the magnitude of this mass extinction, and by studying the response of fossil organisms to the K-Pg we gain valuable geologic and biologic perspectives for understanding the response of contemporary marine life to changing environments in the modern day. 

Intellectual Merit

Our research is part of a larger, interdisciplinary project led by a team of scientists exploring how changes in marine habitats contributed to extinction and evolution during a time of rapid environmental change. Our part of the project focused on two groups of shelled marine creatures that were abundant before and after the extinction: turritellid gastropods (snails) and crassatellid bivalves (clams). We used detailed studies of these fossils to answer several key questions:

  • How did the K-Pg extinction affect the evolutionary relationships within these groups? Did entire lineages disappear, or did some survive and diversify?

  • What clues about their lifestyles (ecology) can we find in their shells, and how did these change across the extinction event?

  • Can studying this ancient mass extinction help us understand and potentially predict the biological impacts of the environmental changes happening today?

Our findings have already contributed new ideas about what occurred over the mass extinction: contrary to earlier assumptions that all GCP turritellid gastropods went extinct at the K-Pg, new analyses of evolutionary relationships in the group indicate that at least two, and possibly up to four, lineages of these snails did indeed survive locally. These survivors gave rise to a diverse array of Paleogene turritellids with similar adult ecology to their pre-extinction relatives, yet they occupied more restricted geographic ranges, likely due to slight declines in their dispersal capability as larvae. This suggests that the environmental pressures faced during and after the extinction played a significant role in shaping the evolution of this group, largely on the basis of their larval ecology.

Phylogenetic analyses of crassatellid bivalves using different methods are revealing complex patterns, including the possibility that crassatellid species once believed to be closely related to one another are actually more distantly related than we thought. Rather, multiple groups in the family evolved similar traits independently in both Cretaceous and Paleocene lineages, resulting in a superficial similarity that obscures our understanding of the true evolutionary history of the group and prevents meaningful investigation of crassatellid extinction drivers.

By building detailed family trees (phylogenies) of these fossil groups, we are gaining a clearer picture of extinction and recovery patterns in the aftermath of a global catastrophe by tracking individual lineages through the event and elucidating the underlying mechanisms driving their adaptive response. This information is crucial for understanding the long-term consequences of mass extinction, and the comprehensive database of GCP fossil occurrences and associated environmental data we’ve compiled will be a valuable resource for future research in this study system.

Broader Impacts

Beyond scientific discoveries, our project is sharing its findings and engaging the wider public by generating resources for teachers and student learners.

We developed a publicly accessible virtual field experience (VFE) designed for high school and introductory college students, with special focus on those living in the Gulf Coast region. Our VFE provides viewers an opportunity to visit Gulf Coastal Plain field locations through a rich array of photographs and videos, and viewers can make observations and answer questions about geology and paleontology in ways that are similar to doing actual fieldwork. In highlighting the experience of doing paleontological research, we hope to encourage students to appreciate what science participation looks like both in and out of the field.

Our project has also helped train the next generation of scientists: this research has supported the development of several early-career female researchers, including a postdoctoral fellow and graduate and undergraduate students, providing them with experiences across a range of activities, including fieldwork, curation, data analysis, and science communication.

Summary

This research project in the U.S. Gulf Coastal Plain is not only uncovering crucial details about one of Earth's most dramatic events, but is also actively engaging the public and training future scientists. By studying the resilience and recovery of marine life after the K-Pg extinction, we can gain a deeper appreciation for the history of our planet and potentially glean valuable lessons for navigating the environmental challenges of our own time.
